title: People flee in panic as skyscraper wobbles in China, despite no earthquake and fine weather
body: People flee in panic as skyscraper wobbles in China, despite no earthquake and fine weatherBy Nectar Gan, CNNUpdated 9:42 AM ET, Wed May 19, 2021 JUST WATCHEDPeople flee as skyscraper wobbles in ChinaReplayMore Videos ...MUST WATCH (17 Videos)People flee as skyscraper wobbles in ChinaIsrael and Hamas agree to ceasefire Local politicians seen at Capitol riot still in high power positionsBiden gets passionate during speech on anti-Asian hate crime billBBC issues apology for 1995 Princess Diana interviewFirst tropical system of the Atlantic hurricane season is likely to form this weekendWatch the moment the House passes bill to create January 6 commissionVideo: 11-year-old girl fights off abductor at bus stopJoe Biden singles out Russia and China in commencement addressBitcoin plunges as China's crypto crackdown widensMcConnell: I made my views about January 6 very clearBody-cam video in shooting of Andrew Brown Jr. shown to public for the first time New York Gov. Cuomo to receive over $5 million from book deal'They aren't moving on': Keilar presses Rev. Graham on election claimsFormer CIA officer describes experience with mysterious illness6-year-old airstrike survivor pulled from rubble'Exasperated': GOP Arizona election official reacts to Trump's election lieHong Kong (CNN)Thousands of shoppers in the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen fled the vicinity of a 957-foot (291-meter) skyscraper Tuesday, after it inexplicably began swaying.Videos circulating on Chinese social media showed crowds running from the wobbling building, with some screaming and looking back over their shoulders. The weather was fine at the time and there were no reports of an earthquake in the region. No deaths or injuries were reported.People in Shenzhen reported to have fled the 73-story SEG Plaza after the building tilted on its foundations. No earthquake recorded in the area https://t.co/OV0g4Luz5Oâ€” Austin Ramzy (@austinramzy) May 18, 2021 The SEG Plaza in Shenzhen began to shake around 12:30 p.m. local time. Some 15,000 people were inside, according to the official newspaper of the Shenzhen Municipal Communist Party Committee. All those inside were evacuated within 90 minutes, local authorities said.Authorities investigating the cause of the shake said in a statement that no "abnormalities in the main structure and surrounding environment of the building" had been found.Read MoreThe city's meteorological station reported a maximum wind speed of around 20 mph (32 kph) at midday Tuesday -- a rate of motion described as a "fresh breeze" by the US National Weather Service.Shoppers look up at the SEG Plaza in Shenzhen after being evacuated from the wobbling building.The tower is located in the busy shopping district of Huaqiangbei, home to the largest electronics market in the world. The building houses various local technology companies and a multistory electronics mall.Completed in 2000, the SEG Plaza is the 18th tallest building in Shenzhen, and the 104th tallest in China, according to the Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat skyscraper database.People flee as skyscraper wobbles in ChinaIsrael and Hamas agree to ceasefire Local politicians seen at Capitol riot still in high power positionsBiden gets passionate during speech on anti-Asian hate crime billBBC issues apology for 1995 Princess Diana interviewFirst tropical system of the Atlantic hurricane season is likely to form this weekendWatch the moment the House passes bill to create January 6 commissionVideo: 11-year-old girl fights off abductor at bus stopJoe Biden singles out Russia and China in commencement addressBitcoin plunges as China's crypto crackdown widensMcConnell: I made my views about January 6 very clearBody-cam video in shooting of Andrew Brown Jr. shown to public for the first time New York Gov.
